summary.name: Aditi Mayer: Sustainable Fashion Influencer Media Production/Distribution Map
summary.description:
Zizi Li’s dissertation research suggests there are two ways in which sustainable fashion influencers relate to supply chains. First, sustainable fashion is deeply embedded in regular supply chains and brand-centered economies. Second, sustainable fashion influencers also engage in the production of alternative supply chains. These engagements often occur through side research projects that accompany more common brand campaigns presented at influencers social media, i.e., Instagram.

Building on this finding, the researcher decided to map these on-the-side research projects. She mapped the locations, communities, events, and other elements this sustainable fashion influencer showcased on her Instagram. For example, in her Instagram, Mayer explains her ethical shift towards sustainable fashion took place after the Rana Plaza collapse in Bangladesh back in 2013. This event is not Mayer’s personal experience but a key event in the recent history of labor struggle in fashion.

A second project showcased is Mayers’ collaboration with the Garment Workers’ Center as part of the campaign “Pay Up Ross.” A third project is “Portraits of Village Economies” in the cotton belt of Punjab. She portrayed these economies as another way of thinking about sustainable fashion. The researcher mapped key locations the influencer identified as part of this sustainable fashion alternative ecosystem. Although presented as an ecosystem, it is clear that this can also be mapped as a supply chain.

Zizi Li, "Aditi Mayer: Sustainable Fashion Influencer Media Production/Distribution Map," Manifest: Supply Chain Platform (2024)

overview.name: Aditi Mayer
overview.description: The creator I am focusing on for this project. Aditi Mayer is an Indian American sustainable fashion influencer, photojournalist, and activist.

overview.name: The Rana Plaza collapse
overview.description: Aditi Mayer credits the Rana Plaza collapse as the catalyst for her to start thinking about the topic of sustainable fashion and labor activism. An eight-storey commercial building called Rana Plaza collapsed on April 24th, 2013 in the Savar Upazila of Dhaka District, Bangladesh. The building housed five garment factories, and the collapse is the deadliest garment industrial disaster with a death toll of 1,134. Nearly 2600 workers were injured, many of them for the rest of their life. On April 23rd, 2013, large cracks were discovered in the building, but the garment factory owners ignored the warnings and forced the workers to return to work the following day. This disatrous incident has garnered massive international attentions and become the turning point in transnational fashion protest campaigns.

overview.name: Garment Worker Center (GWC)
overview.description: Garment Worker Center is a worker rights organization led by low-wage, immigrant garment workers in Los Angeles to eliminate sweatshop labor. It was founded in 2001 following the success of the El Monte garment factory campaign. Aditi Mayer has been publicizing the center's key campaigns through her writings, photojournalist projects, and social media platforms.

overview.name: "Juliana's Journey": Juliana Bautista in "Pay Up, Ross" Campaign
overview.description: Since 2016, the Garment Workers Center has run a "Pay Up, Ross" campaign, after a Department of Labor investigation found 13 factories that produced for YN Apparel, a primary supplier for Ross Stores, had flagrant labor violations — including wages as low as $4 to $5 an hour for 50 to 60 hours of work per week. Four members of the Garment Worker Center worked in these factories, and went on to bring forward wage claims to the California Labor Commission. They won their case and the court ordered that they be paid over $800,000 in back-owed wages. But their owed wages still weren't paid. So garment workers asked Ross Stores to take direct responsibility for the owed wages in its supply chain. Juliana Bautista was one of those workers.

overview.name: "Portraits of Village Economy": Spinners, Weavers, and Farmers in Punjab
overview.description: During her time in Punjab (her parents' home state in India) in 2022, Aditi Mayer talked to farmers in the Malwa region, also known as the Cotton Belt of Punjab. She has a photo series that features portraits of farmers and textile artisans to understand the ecosystem of the rural village economy.

overview.name: Shahpur Jat
overview.description: A market in Delhi with many brands and designer headquarters alongside the workshops of spinners, weavers, embroiderers, dyers, patternmakers and many other building blocks of the fashion industry. Aditi Mayer visited this market to visit some sustainable fashion designers.

location.address: Shahpur Jat, Siri Fort, New Delhi, Delhi 110049, India

overview.name: State of Fashion: "This in an Intervention" Online Exhibition
overview.description: State of Fashion is an international fashion platform where alternatives to the current fashion system are given a stage. With This is an Intervention, State of Fashion reflects on the current state of fashion as well as on its own message and position. Aditi Mayer is a guest editor of Intervention #2: Origins, which dives into the history of fashion’s industrial system and the complex relations between fashion, land and labour in a journey to India. She authored the essay "Sustainability Must Means Decolonization."

overview.name: Kheti Virisat Mission
overview.description: The Kheti Virasat Mission in Punjab is rooted in the mission of reviving the charkha, the type of Indian spinning wheel referenced in the teachings of Mahatma Gandhi, as well as organic farming, conservation of water, biodiversity conservation, seed conservation and more. The organization is featured Aditi Mayer's "Sustainability Must Means Decolonization" essay. Rupsi Garg, the associate director, was featured in "Whataboutery 02 'India’s decolonial approaches to land, labour, and the fashion industry," a panel moderated by Aditi Mayer and hosted by State of Fashion.

location.address: House Number-72, Street Number 4, Jaito-Bajakhana Rd, R.V Shanti Nagar, Jaito, Punjab 151202, India

overview.name: Vandana Shiva
overview.description: Dr. Vandana Shiva is an Indian scientist, environmental activist and focusses on food sovereignty and organic farming. In 1991, she founded Navdanya, a national movement to protect the diversity and integrity of living resources, especially native seed, the promotion of organic farming and fair trade. She was featured in "Whataboutery 02 'India’s decolonial approaches to land, labour, and the fashion industry," a panel moderated by Aditi Mayer and hosted by State of Fashion.

overview.name: Oshadi Collective
overview.description: Oshadi Collective is a contemporary fashion brand designed in London and handmade in India with traditional craft techniques and sustainable materials. Oshadi Collective has created a regenerative fashion supply chain in which farmers regeneratively grow cotton, local weavers turn it into textiles, with even a natural dyeing collective and block printing studio on site. They partner with like-minded brands and designers looking to adopt a thoughtful supply chain and incorporate sustainable practice into their own business. Nishanth Chopra, the foudner, was featured in "Whataboutery 02 'India’s decolonial approaches to land, labour, and the fashion industry," a panel moderated by Aditi Mayer and hosted by State of Fashion.

overview.name: "Matriarch" | Her Farm Nepal
overview.description: In her photo series titled "Matriarch," Aditi Mayer documents Her Farm Nepal, a matriarchal farming community in the foothills of the Himalayas created as a place of refuge for Nepali women who come from backgrounds of gender-based violence.

overview.name: Coach | Coachtopia
overview.description: Coach New York, commonly known as Coach, is an American luxury fashion house specializing in leather handbags, luggage, and accessories, as well as ready-to-wear. Coachtopia is a collaborative lab for innovation within Coach, founded with a mission to accelerate our transition towards a circular economy in fashion by rapidly prototyping new products, processes and ideas. "Coachtopia: The Road to Circularity" is a branded docuseries hosted by Aditi Mayer
